title: AMOXICILLIN - Complete Medication Guide
text:
AMOXICILLIN - Complete Medication Guide

GENERIC NAME: Amoxicillin
BRAND NAMES: Amoxil, Moxatag, Trimox

DRUG CLASS: Penicillin Antibiotic (Aminopenicillin)

MECHANISM OF ACTION:
Amoxicillin is a bactericidal antibiotic that works by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis. It binds to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) inside the bacterial cell wall, inhibiting the transpeptidation step of peptidoglycan synthesis. This weakens the cell wall and leads to osmotic lysis and death of susceptible bacteria. Amoxicillin is effective against gram-positive and some gram-negative bacteria.

INDICATIONS AND USAGE:
- Upper respiratory infections: Pharyngitis, tonsillitis, sinusitis, otitis media
- Lower respiratory infections: Bronchitis, pneumonia
- Skin and skin structure infections
- Urinary tract infections (UTI)
- Helicobacter pylori eradication (with other medications)
- Lyme disease (early stages)
- Prophylaxis for bacterial endocarditis (dental procedures)
- Anthrax exposure (post-exposure prophylaxis)

COMMON BACTERIA COVERED:
- Streptococcus pneumoniae
- Streptococcus pyogenes
- Haemophilus influenzae
- Escherichia coli
- Proteus mirabilis
- Salmonella species
- Enterococcus faecalis
- Helicobacter pylori

DOSAGE GUIDELINES:
Adults:
- Mild to moderate infections: 250-500 mg every 8 hours
- Severe infections: 875 mg every 12 hours
- Maximum dose: 2-3 grams per day

Children (based on weight):
- 20-40 mg/kg/day in divided doses every 8 hours
- 25-45 mg/kg/day in divided doses every 12 hours
- Maximum: 2-3 grams per day

Special populations:
- Renal impairment: Dose adjustment required for CrCl <30 mL/min
- Hemodialysis: Administer after dialysis
- Elderly: Use normal adult dosing unless renal impairment

CONTRAINDICATIONS:
- Known hypersensitivity to penicillins or beta-lactam antibiotics
- History of severe allergic reaction to cephalosporins (cross-sensitivity)
- Infectious mononucleosis (increased risk of rash)

WARNINGS AND PRECAUTIONS:
- Anaphylaxis: Serious allergic reactions can occur (0.01-0.05% of courses)
- Cross-sensitivity: 10% cross-sensitivity with cephalosporins
- Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea: Can occur during or after treatment
- Superinfection: Prolonged use may cause fungal or bacterial overgrowth
- Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction: In treatment of Lyme disease or syphilis
- False-positive urine glucose tests (copper reduction method)

COMMON SIDE EFFECTS:
- Diarrhea (most common, 5-10%)
- Nausea and vomiting
- Abdominal pain
- Rash (especially in patients with mononucleosis)
- Vaginal yeast infection
- Headache
- Altered taste

title: AMOXICILLIN - Complete Medication Guide
text:
SERIOUS SIDE EFFECTS (seek medical attention):
- Severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis): difficulty breathing, hives, swelling
- Clostridium difficile diarrhea: watery/bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping
- Severe skin reactions: Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis
- Seizures (especially with high doses or renal impairment)
- Hepatitis or cholestatic jaundice (rare)
- Interstitial nephritis (rare)

DRUG INTERACTIONS:
1. Probenecid: Increases amoxicillin levels (used intentionally)
2. Methotrexate: Decreased methotrexate elimination, increased toxicity
3. Oral contraceptives: Possibly reduced contraceptive efficacy (use backup method)
4. Allopurinol: Increased risk of rash
5. Warfarin: May increase INR (monitor closely)
6. Typhoid vaccine: Reduced vaccine efficacy
7. Tetracyclines: May interfere with bactericidal action

PREGNANCY AND LACTATION:
- Pregnancy Category B: Generally considered safe
- Crosses placenta but no evidence of fetal harm
- Excreted in breast milk in small amounts
- Generally compatible with breastfeeding (may cause diarrhea in infant)

PHARMACOKINETICS:
- Absorption: Rapidly and well absorbed (75-90% bioavailability)
- Food effect: Not significantly affected by food
- Peak levels: 1-2 hours after oral dose
- Distribution: Widely distributed; crosses placental barrier
- Protein binding: 17-20%
- Metabolism: Partial hepatic metabolism
- Half-life: 60-90 minutes (prolonged in renal impairment)
- Excretion: 60-80% excreted unchanged in urine

SPECTRUM OF ACTIVITY:
Good activity against:
- Streptococcus species
- Enterococcus faecalis
- Listeria monocytogenes
- E. coli (non-ESBL producing)
- Proteus mirabilis
- Salmonella species
- Helicobacter pylori

Limited activity (resistance common):
- Staphylococcus aureus (many strains resistant)
- Klebsiella species
- Pseudomonas aeruginosa
- Anaerobes (better coverage with ampicillin-sulbactam)

RESISTANCE MECHANISMS:
- Beta-lactamase production (most common)
- Altered penicillin-binding proteins
- Reduced permeability
- Efflux pumps

STORAGE:
- Store at room temperature 20-25째C (68-77째F)
- Keep away from moisture and heat
- Oral suspension: Refrigerate after reconstitution, discard after 14 days
- Protect from light

PATIENT EDUCATION:
- Take at evenly spaced intervals to maintain blood levels
- Complete entire course even if feeling better
- Do not share antibiotics with others
- Report any rash or signs of allergic reaction
- Use alternative contraception if on birth control pills
- Probiotics may help prevent diarrhea
- Shake oral suspension well before use

title: IBUPROFEN - Complete Medication Guide
text:
IBUPROFEN - Complete Medication Guide

GENERIC NAME: Ibuprofen
BRAND NAMES: Advil, Motrin, Nurofen, Caldolor

DRUG CLASS: Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drug (NSAID)

MECHANISM OF ACTION:
Ibuprofen works by inhibiting the enzymes cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2). These enzymes are responsible for producing prostaglandins, which are chemical messengers that cause inflammation, pain, and fever in the body. By blocking these enzymes, ibuprofen reduces the production of prostaglandins, leading to decreased pain and inflammation.

INDICATIONS AND USAGE:
- Mild to moderate pain relief (headache, toothache, backache)
- Fever reduction
- Inflammation reduction (arthritis, muscle strains)
- Menstrual cramps (dysmenorrhea)
- Minor aches and pains

DOSAGE GUIDELINES:
Adults and children over 12 years:
- 200-400mg every 4-6 hours as needed
- Do not exceed 1200mg per day without doctor supervision
- Take with food or milk to reduce stomach upset

Children (under 12):
- Weight-based dosing: 5-10mg/kg every 6-8 hours
- Maximum: 40mg/kg per day

CONTRAINDICATIONS:
- Known hypersensitivity to ibuprofen or other NSAIDs
- History of asthma attacks after taking NSAIDs
- Active peptic ulcer disease or GI bleeding
- Severe heart failure (NYHA class III-IV)
- Late pregnancy (third trimester, can cause premature closure of ductus arteriosus)
- Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery perioperative pain

WARNINGS AND PRECAUTIONS:
- Cardiovascular risk: May increase risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events
- Gastrointestinal risk: Can cause GI bleeding, ulceration, and perforation
- Renal effects: Can reduce renal blood flow, risk in elderly or dehydrated patients
- Hepatic effects: Rare cases of severe liver injury
- Anaphylactoid reactions: Can occur in patients with aspirin triad

COMMON SIDE EFFECTS:
- Nausea and vomiting
- Heartburn and dyspepsia
- Diarrhea or constipation
- Dizziness and headache
- Drowsiness

SERIOUS SIDE EFFECTS (seek medical attention):
- Signs of stomach bleeding: black/bloody stools, coffee-ground vomit
- Signs of heart attack: chest pain, shortness of breath
- Signs of stroke: sudden numbness, confusion, vision changes
- Signs of allergic reaction: rash, hives, difficulty breathing
- Signs of liver problems: dark urine, yellowing skin/eyes

title: IBUPROFEN - Complete Medication Guide
text:
DRUG INTERACTIONS:
1. Warfarin (Coumadin): SEVERE - Increased bleeding risk
2. Aspirin: MODERATE - Increased GI side effects, reduced cardioprotection
3. Lisinopril (ACE inhibitors): MODERATE - Reduced blood pressure effect
4. Metformin: MODERATE - Possible increased metformin levels
5. Furosemide (diuretics): MODERATE - Reduced diuretic effect
6. Lithium: MODERATE - Increased lithium levels, risk of toxicity
7. Methotrexate: MODERATE - Increased methotrexate toxicity
8. SSRIs (antidepressants): MILD - Increased bleeding risk

PHARMACOKINETICS:
- Absorption: Well absorbed orally (80-85% bioavailability)
- Onset of action: 30-60 minutes
- Peak plasma levels: 1-2 hours
- Protein binding: 90-99% bound to plasma proteins
- Metabolism: Hepatic via CYP2C9
- Half-life: 2-4 hours
- Excretion: Urine (primarily as metabolites, <1% unchanged)

STORAGE:
- Store at room temperature 20-25째C (68-77째F)
- Keep away from moisture and heat
- Protect from light

title: WARFARIN - Complete Medication Guide
text:
WARFARIN - Complete Medication Guide

GENERIC NAME: Warfarin
BRAND NAMES: Coumadin, Jantoven

DRUG CLASS: Anticoagulant (Vitamin K Antagonist)

MECHANISM OF ACTION:
Warfarin inhibits the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is responsible for recycling vitamin K, which is essential for the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X in the liver. By blocking this enzyme, warfarin reduces the production of these clotting factors, leading to a decreased ability for blood to clot. The full anticoagulant effect takes 3-5 days because existing clotting factors must naturally degrade.

INDICATIONS AND USAGE:
- Prophylaxis and treatment of venous thrombosis (deep vein thrombosis, DVT)
- Prophylaxis and treatment of pulmonary embolism (PE)
- Prevention of thromboembolic events in atrial fibrillation
- Prevention of thromboembolic events after heart valve replacement
- Reduction of risk of recurrent myocardial infarction
- Prevention of stroke in patients with mechanical heart valves

DOSAGE GUIDELINES:
- Initial dose: 2-5 mg daily (based on patient factors)
- Maintenance dose: 2-10 mg daily (individualized based on INR)
- Dose adjustments based on International Normalized Ratio (INR)
- Target INR depends on indication:
  * Most indications: 2.0-3.0
  * Mechanical heart valves: 2.5-3.5
- Take at same time each day (usually evening)

CONTRAINDICATIONS:
- Active bleeding or hemorrhagic tendencies
- Pregnancy (warfarin embryopathy, especially first trimester)
- Recent or upcoming surgery (including dental surgery)
- Severe uncontrolled hypertension
- Pericarditis or pericardial effusion
- Lumbar puncture or regional anesthesia
- Inability to comply with monitoring requirements

WARNINGS AND PRECAUTIONS:
- Bleeding risk: Most serious adverse effect
- Monitoring: Regular INR testing required (initially weekly, then monthly)
- Dietary consistency: Vitamin K intake should be consistent
- Drug interactions: Hundreds of drugs interact with warfarin
- Genetic factors: CYP2C9 and VKORC1 variants affect metabolism
- "Warfarin necrosis": Rare skin necrosis complication

COMMON SIDE EFFECTS:
- Bleeding (epistaxis, gum bleeding, easy bruising)
- Purplish toes (cholesterol microembolization)
- Hair loss (reversible)
- Skin rash
- Nausea and vomiting
- Abdominal pain

SERIOUS SIDE EFFECTS (seek immediate medical attention):
- Severe bleeding (internal, intracranial)
- Signs of bleeding: black stools, blood in urine, coffee-ground vomit
- Sudden severe headache (possible intracranial bleed)
- Unexplained bruising or swelling
- Warfarin-induced skin necrosis
- Purple toe syndrome

title: WARFARIN - Complete Medication Guide
text:
DRUG INTERACTIONS (SIGNIFICANT):
SEVERE INTERACTIONS:
1. Ibuprofen and other NSAIDs: Increased bleeding risk
2. Aspirin: Significantly increased bleeding risk
3. Amiodarone: Increased warfarin effect (monitor INR closely)
4. Fluconazole (antifungals): Increased warfarin effect
5. Metronidazole: Increased warfarin effect
6. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Increased warfarin effect

MODERATE INTERACTIONS:
1. Acetaminophen (high doses, regular use): Increased INR
2. Amoxicillin: Increased warfarin effect (disrupts gut flora)
3. Ciprofloxacin: Increased warfarin effect
4. Omeprazole: Possible increased warfarin effect
5. Simvastatin: Possible increased warfarin effect
6. Phenytoin: Complex bidirectional interaction
7. Alcohol (chronic heavy use): Variable effects

INTERACTIONS THAT DECREASE WARFARIN EFFECT:
1. Vitamin K (dietary supplements)
2. Rifampin
3. Barbiturates
4. Carbamazepine
5. Cholestyramine
6. Oral contraceptives

DIETARY CONSIDERATIONS:
- Consistent vitamin K intake is crucial
- Vitamin K rich foods: leafy greens (kale, spinach, broccoli, Brussels sprouts)
- Do not eliminate these foods, but keep intake consistent
- Avoid cranberry juice (may increase warfarin effect)
- Avoid alcohol (especially binge drinking)
- Avoid herbal supplements: St. John's wort, ginseng, ginkgo, coenzyme Q10

PHARMACOKINETICS:
- Absorption: Rapid and complete oral absorption
- Bioavailability: >95%
- Protein binding: 99% bound to albumin
- Metabolism: Hepatic via CYP2C9
- Half-life: 20-60 hours (average 40 hours)
- Onset of action: 24-72 hours
- Duration of action: 2-5 days
- Monitoring: INR (International Normalized Ratio)

LABORATORY MONITORING:
- INR target: Individualized (typically 2-3)
- Frequency: Initially daily to weekly, then every 4 weeks when stable
- Check INR before any surgical procedure
- Pregnancy: Warfarin contraindicated (heparin used instead)

PATIENT EDUCATION POINTS:
- Take exactly as prescribed at same time daily
- Missed dose: Take if remembered same day, otherwise skip
- Never double up doses
- Report any unusual bleeding or bruising
- Use soft toothbrush and electric razor
- Avoid contact sports
- Carry medical alert identification
- Inform all healthcare providers of warfarin use
- Keep all appointments for INR testing
- Do not start or stop any medication without consulting prescriber
